doesn't this fail if input is a InputColumn symbol?
I also don't completely get why the changes in this class are related/needed...

To make it possible to get a doc values aggregator for cases like sum(long_column::numeric).
The aggregation, in this case, will be a cast function symbol with the numeric value type,
so it would not be possible to resolve DocValueAggregator later on because we would try to get it for the wrong type that is not in the list of to collect symbols. Therefore, if we face the cast function we have to visit its argument and apply the logic we had before, checking if it is a reference or input column symbol. See https://github.com/crate/crate/pull/10854/files#diff-f655e047f75c5f53c3c464715b73f94c02b3fa19f62209ea606a4f3d9cfec7d8R163-R169

Ah I see, function traversal is needed, but isn't this already required on the master when doing something like sum(long_column::int)? Looks like a bugfix, not?
Other than that, I still think that the logic is a bit shaky as with the new ReferenceOrInputColumnSymbolExtractor theoretically a InputColumn is returned while this function resolveInputToFieldType is requiring a Reference.
If we expect the return type to be a Reference (which is afaik always the case) we should make that clear inside the code and fail on everything else.

Ah I see, function traversal is needed, but isn't this already required on the master when doing something like sum(long_column::int)? Looks like a bugfix, not?

You are right, it is the case on the master already. Maybe I'll extract this part and make a PR against master, but not sure whether it is a bug because the doc values optimization is not just applied in that case, nothing gets broken.

Other than that, I still think that the logic is a bit shaky as with the new ReferenceOrInputColumnSymbolExtractor theoretically a InputColumn is returned while this function resolveInputToFieldType is requiring a Reference.

Agree 👍  will refine that

Ah I see, function traversal is needed, but isn't this already required on the master when doing something like sum(long_column::int)? Looks like a bugfix, not?

it is not a bug on, master. this case is not implemented, I'll add just a support it for the numeric cast only. I'll try to follow up on it on this week.
why not calling .setScale on the original value?

We also have to set the precision, it is done via the math context.
If we set the scale on the original value, smth like that might result in an incorrect result
('some value'::numeric(16))::numeric(4, 2)
Ah right, I missed the precision part via the math context. Thanks for the explanation.
why is the intermediate BigInteger used here instead of passing the string directly?
I'll have to double-check that, but I think coz the string can already contain a scaled value.
couldn't this be folded into the String branch?
just adding 1L once should be enough and keeps this simpler
actually, calling the .add twice will test different parts of the code. so all fine, ignore my comment ;-)

Shouldn't the returnType default to numeric anyway because of the signature definition?
Not sure I understand the reasoning here.
If we later on add supports for numeric type storage we shouldn't have to adjust aggregation functions.

Yes, the return type defaults to numeric, but with the default precision and 0 scale.  If we do smth like sum(count::numeric(16, 2)) we will lose the precision and scale information in the return type, so currently that is the only way I think, otherwise, we would need to have use type variables instead of numeric in the sum signature and somehow make it work also with other types.
See comment about avoiding toByteArray in the size estimator class

Same here.
I'm also not sure if partialResult is the right place for the accounting. partialResult is called at the end of the aggregation, long after the allocations and resizes already happened.
I think doing this in initialState or as needed would be safer
I put into partialResult because we do not know how big the big decimal can be at the end. Would you suggest just to put some apprx. into initialState like for example 4 bytes?
Yes I think its important to account that at earliest as possible, meaning accounting for the min size at initialState and adjusting it on iterate.
Should we maybe add a test in crate-qa with asyncpg or so, to verify that this can be read? Or is this covered already somewhere?
not really, only in unit tests. would it be enough to go for an integration pg test in crate/crate?
If the jdbc client supports binary serialization for numeric types that's also possible, yes.
There's  writeByteArray and readByteArray which could be used
